urn:contentItem:5MHV-HGK1-JD34-V3TN-00000-00Campers urged to be aware2017-01-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:19ZLexisNexisINSIDE FRONTCampers urged to be aware

HOLIDAYMAKERS are reminded to check the weather forecast and fire danger before heading into the Hume region's forests and parks.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's assistant chief fire officer - Hume Gill Metz said people should always keep in mind the potential for bushfires. Tips include taking plenty of food, water and extra fuel and packing sturdy footwear, a set of woollen clothing and a woollen blanket.

"Remember the weather can change rapidly," Ms Metz said.

urn:contentItem:5R1B-Y0M1-F0J6-J54C-00000-00Firewood collection season to close2017-11-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 11Firewood collection season to closeAnthony Piovesan

The spring 2017 firewood collection season will close across the Grampians region on Thursday, November 30.

All designated firewood collection areas will be closed over the summer period and it will be illegal for people to collect firewood on public land until the start of the autumn firewood collection season as of Friday, December 1.

On-the-spot fines are about $622.

Forest Fire Management Victoria acting and assistant fire control officer Peter Kambouris said firewood collection may already have ceased in some parts of the state where supplies were exhausted or where rainfall or flooding had affected track conditions, making collection unsafe," he said.

"The public will be able to start collecting firewood again from designated firewood collection areas from the March 1, 2018, pending suitable conditions."

FOREST Fire Management and Parks Victoria will conduct a planned burn at Glenorchy on Friday.

The burn will target about 34 hectares in the Arapiles and Lower Bunbury street areas, about 500 metres to the west of Glenorchy.

Residents are advised smoke may be visible for the duration of the hazard reduction burn.

Access to walking tracks, car parks, camping grounds and picnic sites in the areas close to or in burn areas could be restricted.

urn:contentItem:5S5S-NGP1-JD34-V3C6-00000-00444 hectare planned burn for the Grampians2018-04-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:19ZLexisNexis444 hectare planned burn for the Grampians

A planned burn for Victoria Valley Road in the Grampians will start on Thursday.

Forest Fire Management Victoria and the CFA plan on burning 444 hectares, if the weather conditions permit.

The burn will go for multiple days from Thursday to Sunday.

FFMV and the CFA have advised some people may be affected by the smoke.

The Department of Health and Human Services advises anyone experiencing symptoms of smoke exposure to seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024.

The FFMV and the CFA also advise people to close windows and doors to prevent smoke from entering, if affected by smoke exposure.

Access to walking tracks, car parks, camping grounds and picnic sites in areas close to or in burn areas may be restricted.

Road's may be hazardous for motorists due to low visibility linked to the smoke, so signs may be placed to slow traffic.

To stay informed of the burn download the Vic Emergency app or call the VicEmergency Hotline on 1800 226 226.

urn:contentItem:5S5S-NGP1-JD34-V2VY-00000-00Planned burn to be carried out in Harcourt and Mount Alexander2018-04-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:19ZLexisNexisPlanned burn to be carried out in Harcourt and Mount Alexander

Fuel reduction burns will be conducted in Harcourt and Mount Alexander this week.

Forest Fire Management Victoria and the CFA will carry out the planned burns on seven hectares in the Mount Alexander Regional Park, four kilometres east of Harcourt on Wednesday and Thursday.

This burn should be completed between 9am and 8pm on Wednesday but smoke may be visible until Thursday 26 April.

Smoke may be visible from Castlemaine, Harcourt, Sutton Grange and surrounding areas.

Road travel may be hazardous due to low visibility associated with smoke and access to walking tracks, car parks, camping grounds and picnic sites in areas close to or in burn areas may be restricted.

Anyone affected by smoke exposure, should seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024.

For parks closures, please refer to Parks Victoria on 13 1963 or visit http://parkweb.vic.gov.au/

For more details on planned burns in Victoria visit www.ffm.vic.gov.au/plannedburn

urn:contentItem:5MYS-SYX1-F0J6-J25M-00000-00Bridge replacement sees popular campsite closed2017-02-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Bridge replacement sees popular campsite closedJohn Chanter

Lightning Creek campsite, south of Mitta Mitta, will be closed for up to five months - including Easter - while the access bridge is replaced.

The single access bridge, built in the early 1960s, is being replaced as part of a $400,000 project to improve access for fire fighters and heavy machinery.

"The contractor will be on-site from late-February with works on the removal of the existing bridge to commence from early March 2017," Forest Fire Management Victoria's Aaron Kennedy said.

urn:contentItem:5RJD-HC91-JD34-V3YM-00000-00Bushfire at Glenpatrick now contained, no threat to commuities2018-01-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:19ZLexisNexisBushfire at Glenpatrick now contained, no threat to commuitiesRochelle Kirkham

UPDATE: A bushfire at Glenpatrick is now contained.

There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.

Firefighters will continue to patrol the fire throughout the afternoon.

Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads.

EARLIER: Five vehicles are responding to a bushfire at Glenpatrick near Ampitheatre that is not yet under control.

There is currently no threat to communities, but residents in Ampitheatre, Glenpatrick and Warrenmang have been advised to continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.

CFA and Forest Fire Management Victoria fire fighters are currently on scene.

Aircraft and heavy machinery have also been working on the fire which is in a hard to access area.

Bracewell Street in Eaglehawk, 5.2km west of Bendigo, will have a 77-hectare reduction burn on Tuesday.

In Kamarooka, 33kms north of Bendigo, Camp Street will have a 95-hectare reduction burn on Tuesday.

urn:contentItem:5S2F-JJR1-F0JP-W4PD-00000-00Planned burn for Otways2018-04-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8Planned burn for OtwaysChad Van Estrop

A PLANNED 48-hectare burn will take place in the Otways today. Forty firefighters will light dense forest and dry woodland near the Forrest-Apollo Bay Rd, south of the Forrest township.

Forest Fire Management Victoria controller David Rourke said the burn would significantly reduce the bushfire risk around infrastructure supplying water to Forrest.

"Monday's planned burn will complement the planned burn that was completed over the weekend to protect Forrest from fires approaching from the west and southwest," Mr Rourke said.

"Removing bushfire fuel along the Forrest-Apollo Bay Rd will reduce the speed and intensity of fires approaching from the southwest." Mr Rourke said mountain bike trails around Forrest including the Forrest Loop, Barlidjaru, and part of the Red Carpet trail, would be closed during the burn."Forrest residents will be able to see and smell smoke, and smoke may be visible from Gerangamete, Barwon Downs, Barramunga and Colac," he said.

urn:contentItem:5RVK-S051-F0J6-J2KF-00000-00Planned burns beginPlanned bur...2018-03-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 6Planned burns beginPlanned bur...

Planned burns begin

Planned burning has started across Victoria to reduce bushfire risk. Forest Fire Management Victoria and the Country Fire Authority (CFA) are carrying out the burns throughout autumn. For more information visit ffm.vic.gov.au/plannedburn or download the VicEmergency app.

Program helps parents

Melton families facing disadvantage will benefit from a $22.1 million expansion of the state government's supported playgroups program, which helps parents improve their skills and gain more confidence in looking after their children. More local families will now be able to access the service, such as those experiencing family violence, breakdown or social isolation, thanks to a widened eligibility criteria.

Inclusive school facilities

Teachers and students are being encouraged to think about how they can improve school facilities for students with disabilities or special needs. Round four of the Inclusive School Fund program is now open for schools to come up with projects based on their existing facilities. The Inclusive Schools Fund will deliver $6 million to schools across the state in this round.

urn:contentItem:5SXF-B3P1-F0JP-W2S9-00000-00Blaze death toll up to 912018-07-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 15Blaze death toll up to 91

THE official death toll from a wildfire that raged through a coastal area east of Athens has risen to 91, with 25 people missing, six days after -Europe's deadliest forest fire in more than a century.

Hundreds of people attended a Sunday morning memorial service for victims in the seaside village hardest-hit by the blaze.

The fire spread flames through the village of Mati, a popular resort spot, without warning on July 23.

Most victims died in the fire itself, but a number drowned in the sea while fleeing the flames.

At the memorial service in Mati, the senior local Greek Orthodox Church official, Bishop Kyrillos, said the community was grieving the simultaneous loss of family, neighbours and friends.

"There's fewer of us now than usually," he said. "It is the victims of the recent fire that are missing - friends, relatives and acquaintances â€¦ people that we saw every day in town and on the beach."Angeliki Galiatsatou said she narrowly escaped the fire that had killed others in their cars and homes. "I came to pray for the people who were lost," she said.

urn:contentItem:5PVW-VSN1-JD3N-5562-00000-00Otways tracks to reopen2017-11-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 12Otways tracks to reopenOLIVIA SHYING

FOREST and park tracks and roads across the Otway district will reopen this weekend, in time for the Melbourne Cup break.

Forest Fire Management Victoria senior forest management and roading officer Craig Clifford said roads and tracks were closed to protect them from damage during wetter months as part of the seasonal road closure program.

"These roads and tracks were closed over winter and spring for public safety and to protect track surfaces as well as water quality and the forest environment," he said.

"However, we want people to be mindful of the campfire regulations and ensure that campfires are maintained and left in a safe condition." Visitors are encouraged to obtain the most up-to-date information- on access to forest and park areas before they travel at parksweb.vic.gov.au.

urn:contentItem:5NCH-BNG1-JD34-V18M-00000-00SA Fire Fighters Memorial Service | PHOTOS,VIDEO2017-04-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:19ZLexisNexisSA Fire Fighters Memorial Service | PHOTOS,VIDEO

A pleasing crowd gathered at the SA Volunteer Fire Fighters Memorial in Naracoorte on Saturday morning to honour the lives of eight fallen Forestry SA fire fighters.

Distinguished guests and members of the public witnessed the unveiling of a plaque which paid tribute to the the men who died in the Wandilo Forest Fire on April 5, 1958.

Forestry SA chief executive Jerome Coleman, CFS chief officer Greg Nettleton and SA Volunteer Fire Fighters chair Rex Hall all made speeches in the hour long service.

More coverage of the memorial in next week's Naracoorte Herald.

urn:contentItem:5RRY-X4W1-JD34-V1C9-00000-00fires2018-02-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3fires

Multiple fires broke out across Ballarat on Sunday afternoon, closing roads and requiring a huge effort from Country Fire Authority units.

Two grass fires started near the Western Freeway and the Creswick Road/Midland Highway overpass about 2pm, while a third broke out in Napoleons about 2.30pm.

District 15 duty officer Kade Dowie praised efforts.

He said 20 CFA appliances, a fire bombing helicopter and an observation air craft attended the Western Freeway fire, while 12 crews were on scene in Napoleons.

Crews remained at the site of the Western Freeway fires overnight to patrol and mop up the flanks of the fire.

Duty officer Dowie said the CFA and Victoria Police were investigating the causes of the fires, as well as determining whether the Western Freeway fires were part of the same fire or separate.

He said it had been very lucky that there had been no structural damage or injuries at any of the fires, but potentially fencing had been damaged.

Forest Fire Management Victoria was helping to clean up trees in the area.

urn:contentItem:5N7W-VRS1-F0J6-J3KM-00000-00Firefighters take out top prize2017-04-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 9Firefighters take out top prize

Two Bendigo firefighters have won gold at the 2017 Police and Emergency Services Games in Melbourne.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's Beth Miley and the CFA's Tegan Bubb took out the Crossfit women's pairs event last week.

"Crossfit's a high-intensity fitness program that incorporates elements from several sports and types of exercise such as weightlifting and gymnastics," Ms Miley said.

"It is a very demanding sport and we were estatic to win the gold."

The Emergency Service Games were an annual sporting event emphasising camaraderie, fitness, health, and wellbeing.

The 10 day event included more than 40 sports, including equestrian events in Elmore.

urn:contentItem:5R14-C7C1-JD3N-5215-00000-00BUNYIP FIRE IN CONTROL2017-11-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4BUNYIP FIRE IN CONTROLGenevieve Alison and Sophie Smith

FIREFIGHTERS have worked overnight to contain a bushfire that tore through 26ha of Bunyip State Park yesterday.

Incident Controller Nigel Brennan last night expected the blaze would be totally contained overnight.

More than 50 Forest Fire Management and CFA firefighters fought the blaze, which started about 1pm and was travelling north from Tonimbuk Rd, near Gembrook. They last night had stopped its spread near Burgess Rd.

"Crews are currently being supported by Helitaks and surveillance aircraft, and bulldozers are being used to build control lines around the perimeter of the fire," Mr Brennan said.

An advice message remained in place for the Gembrook community, with nearby residents warned to stay informed and monitor conditions.

The bushfire comes as temperatures are expected to remain in the low 30s for the next three days.This week, Melbourne has experienced one of the longest and hottest November weather streaks in 155 years.

urn:contentItem:5RJD-HC91-JD34-V3X3-00000-00Big Desert fire under control; road reopened2018-01-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:19ZLexisNexisBig Desert fire under control; road reopenedCarly Werner

FIRFIGHTERS have controlled a blaze in the Big Desert Wilderness Park that has been burning for more than a week.

Forest Fire Management Victoria crews controlled the fire about 5pm on Saturday, and the Nhill-Murrayville Road has been reopened.

A management group spokeswoman said the road was in poor condition in some sections because of heavy traffic in the past week, and advised people to reduce speed and drive to the conditions.

She said firefighters were still in the area, patrolling the 85-kilometre fire edge.

The fire has burnt about 5600 hectares since it started on Friday, January 19.

Water bombers and an air tanker helped with the fire fight during the week.

The fire was in a largely remote area and did not pose a risk to any communities, however authorities issued advice messages for people in the Underbool, Big Desert, Telopea Downs, Boinka, Carina, Cowangie, Danyo, Murrayville, Ngallo, Panitya, Tutye and Waggon Flat areas.

urn:contentItem:5S2S-GBT1-F0JP-W1W5-00000-00Forest too dry for burn-offs2018-04-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Forest too dry for burn-offsBy PETER HUNT

MORE than 200,000ha of Crown land across Victoria has been targeted for planned burns this year, but unseasonally dry conditions are hampering the efforts of CFA and Forest Fire Management Victoria's crews to get the job done.

The lack of rain since January has left the state's forests tinder dry, forcing crews to focus their planned burns on high-priority areas - the Otway Ranges, Wombat State Forest and Dandenong Ranges.

Since this year's program kicked off last month, about 148 planned burns have been conducted across 8247ha.

"We work closely with the Bureau of Meteorology to assess weather conditions such as humidity, temperature and wind speed and will only carry out burns when conditions are suitable," Department of Environment, Land Water and Planning chief fire officer Darrin McKenzie said.In the meantime FFMVic is slashing and mulching areas that are too dry to burn, removing hazardous trees, upgrading fire tracks and preparing sites so they can be burned at short notice, when conditions improve.

urn:contentItem:5R9W-VVB1-F0J6-J0F9-00000-00Look out for chainsaws2018-01-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 9Look out for chainsawsRebecca Fist

In Myola, Shoalhaven City Council rangers discovered two tall eucalyptus trees had been felled on Monday.

The huge, 30-year old trees were found near the road on the Black Forest fire trail.

Rangers suspect the culprit may return to the scene to cut the trees up for fire wood.

Council rangers director Michael Jarman has urged the public to contact him, or the Shoalhaven police with any information on the crime.

"If you see anyone walking around with a chainsaw take a photo of their car registration, and ring council or the local police straight away," he said.

Mr Jarman asked the public for tips via Facebook but has not had any success at this stage.

Locally in the past, residents have been issued with on the spot fines of $1500 for each tree felled on public land, and $8000 for cases that went to the Land and Environment Court.

Contact council's rangers on 4429 3433.

urn:contentItem:5RB9-PPG1-JD34-V4RG-00000-00firefighters on standby2018-01-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2firefighters on standbyNatalie Croxon

A total fire ban has been declared for the whole of Victoria this Saturday, with firefirefighters preparing to confront soaring temperatures and strong winds.

The CFA made the announcement yesterday, with fire danger rating across Victoria ranging from very high to extreme.

Simon Brown, from Forest Fire Management Victoria, said crews and two firefighting aircraft were on call.

Fire towers have been activated at several locations, including Bendigo, Mount Tarrengower and Mount Macedon, among others.

"We're urging anyone going camping, especially on Saturday, to be very careful and plan ahead," Mr Brown said.

He said people should have an escape route planned should they be cut off by a bushfire.

Campfires are banned on total fire ban days, but on other days, people should use a purpose-built fireplace where provided or light a campfire in a trench at least 30 centimetres deep and no larger one square metre,

They must also ensure there is no flammable material within three metres.

urn:contentItem:5RB9-PPG1-JD34-V43Y-00000-00Discover state forest secrets with interactive app2018-01-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 10Discover state forest secrets with interactive appSophie Boyd

An interactive app will reveal the wide range of activities available in Victorian state forests.

Forest Fire Management's More to Explore app wants to encourage people to explore the region's natural environments.

The app provides real-time information, to show users trails and sites that suit their needs from camping, walking, fishing, four-wheel-driving or mountain biking.

Minister for Energy, Environment and Climate Change Lily D'Ambrosio said the app contains details on almost 400 campaign and picnic sites and more than 240 recreational trails.

"With more than three million hectares of State Forest to explore in Victoria, this app will make it quicker and easier for everyone to discover our state's breathtaking natural beauty," she said.

The app allows users to plan their trip before they have left home and maps can be downloaded onto phones to enable offline navigation, to assist people planning to explore areas with limited phone range.

urn:contentItem:5SXF-B3P1-F0JP-W3DV-00000-00Greek village grieves as wildfire death toll rises2018-07-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 11Greek village grieves as wildfire death toll rises

MATI: The death toll from a wildfire that raged through a coastal area of Greece, east of Athens, has increased to 91.

Fire officials have reported that 25 people remain missing six days after Europe's deadliest forest fire in more than a century.

Hundreds of mourners attended a Sunday morning memorial service for the victims in the seaside village hardest-hit by the blaze.

The fire sped through the village of Mati, a popular resort spot, without warning on July 23. A database maintained by the Centre for the Research on the Epidemiology of Disasters in Brussels shows it to be the deadliest wildfire in Europe since 1900.

The majority of victims died in the fire itself, although some drowned in the sea while fleeing the flames.

Until Sunday night, Greek officials had not provided a tally of the people reported missing, but said 59 victims had been identified and another four injured in the fire had died in area hospitals.

Another 28 sets of remains are to be identified and 25 people are officially missing.

Greek authorities believe the fire resulted from arson and turned so deadly because of winds of up to 100km/h in thepine-forested seaside towns.

urn:contentItem:5R6G-7BM1-JD34-V0D2-00000-00sidey - poss spill?2017-12-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2sidey - poss spill?Emma D'Agostino

AN UNATTENDED camp fire at Mount Alexander has sparked warnings from authorities ahead of a couple of sweltering days.

Forest Fire Management Victoria, the Country Fire Brigade and Victoria Police have implored people to heed the restrictions and regulations in place and avoid unnecessary fires.

Firefighters were called about 1.30pm on Sunday after smoke was sighted at the peak of Mt Alexander.

Units were quick to respond, with two CFA helicopters deployed to assist.

Castlemaine Sergeant Mick Peckham said the source of the smoke was found to be an unattended camp fire at Picnic Point - an area at the top of the mountain.

The camp fire had spread to adjacent grass and scrub, burning through an area about 20 metres by 10 metres.

Sergeant Peckham said the fire was believed to be the result of carelessness, as opposed to a malicious act. But investigations are ongoing.

He urged anyone with information to call their local police station or to make an anonymous report to Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.

THE State Government is reducing the bushfire risk across Victoria with burns planned in the Yarra Ranges.

Forest Fire Management Victoria and the CFA would concentrate on burning both private and public property on the urban fringes including the Dandenong Ranges, which would happen in March.

Government chief fire officer Stephanie Rotarangi said autumn weather was predicted to be good for bushfire reduction.

"Working with the CFA is a vital part of the planned burning program to make sure we are using local knowledge to manage bushfire risk together to deliver maximum benefit to the community," Ms Rotarangi said.For more information, visit the website vic.gov.au/plannedburn

urn:contentItem:5RKN-75D1-F0JP-W19B-00000-00FIRE AT POWER STATION2018-02-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 15FIRE AT POWER STATIONERIN PEARSON and TAMARA McDonald

FIRE CREWS responded to a structure fire at Alcoa's Anglesea power station yesterday.

Emergency services were alerted to fire after reports of flames in a condenser, off Camp Rd, shortly before 3pm.

The Anglesea mine and power plant closed in 2015.

District 07 operations officer Wayne Aylmer yesterday said the fire had been contained by 5pm, but was still being extinguished.

Mr Aylmer said the disused condenser unit was made of magnesium and titanium. "These materials can prove difficult to extinguish, fortunately the condenser unit is surrounded by mineral earth," Mr Aylmer said. "Our priority is to cool the condenser unit down and extinguish with mineral earth. The former power station is surrounded by a national park, Forest Fire Management Victoria firefighters are supporting CFA by monitoring the surroundings ensuring this fire does not spread into bushlands."Mr Aylmer said the structure on fire was about 15m x 10m. There was a "significant amount" of smoke billowing from the fire, but the smoke was no risk to the site, he said.

urn:contentItem:5RKK-2PK1-JD34-V4FG-00000-00spring gully fire2018-02-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3spring gully fireNatalie Croxon

Authorities are treating a small fire in Spring Gully on Sunday afternoon as suspicious.

CFA and Forest Fire Management Victoria attended the fire in the Spring Gully Creek Reserve, near the soccer fields, shortly before 5pm.

Emergency services were alerted when the smoke was spotted from the One Tree Hill fire tower.

It took crews about 20 minutes to bring the fire under control, with a firefighting helicopter assisting in the effort.

FFM Victoria senior fire management officer Jeff Wilkie said the fire burnt an area about one-quarter of a hectare in size.

With no lightning and it being an area frequented often by the public, Mr Wilkie said the cause of the fire was being treated as suspicious, although misadventure was also a possibility.

Mr Wilkie said it was lucky it was a milder day, as in hotter, windier weather, the fire could have had the potential to cause more damage.

Anyone who might have seen or heard anything related to the Spring Gully fire is asked to contact Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.

urn:contentItem:5P88-0N11-JD34-V275-00000-00Top honours for Black Saturday efforts2017-08-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Top honours for Black Saturday efforts

Two south-west men have been honoured for their efforts in the Black Saturday fires.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's Peter Scott and Raymond Albert have both received National Emergency Medals for their efforts during the state's worst natural disaster.

Mr Scott was the operations officer in the incident control centre at Heywood, managing a team that was monitoring and providing guidance to staff on the ground.

Mr Albert, from Dartmoor, was part of a Far South West taskforce unit involved in the firefighting efforts.

Barwon South West assistant chief fire officer Andrew Morrow said the courage and strength of all who responded to the devastating Black Saturday fires in 2009 should be commended for their work.

"This month we're very proud to recognise the efforts of Peter Scott and Raymond Albert, who have 80 years of fire service between them," Mr Morrow said.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's Peter Scott and Raymond Albert have both received National Emergency Medals for their efforts during the state's worst natural disaster.

Mr Scott was the operations officer in the incident control centre at Heywood, managing a team that was monitoring and providing guidance to staff on the ground.

urn:contentItem:5PTK-4HD1-F0JP-W0DX-00000-00Bush blaze warning as crews tackle fires2017-10-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 37Bush blaze warning as crews tackle firesMITCH MOTT

A HARD hitting advertising campaign is warning residents in suburbs on the fringes of Adelaide and larger towns to not be complacent about the risks posed by bushfires.

The advert with the sombre message "Complacency Kills" will launch this weekend. Yesterday was the first day of the year to have multiple districts declared total fire bans.

Grass and stubble fires affected Coober Pedy, Mylor, Eden Hills, Yalata, Davenport, Kudla and Waitpinga.

A controlled burn reignited in Waitpinga with four crews battling to keep the remote fire away from a property.

Multiple CFS crews attended a haystack fire in Mallala, fighting to keep the intense blaze contained while a large hay fire continues to smoulder in Laura.

A forest fire in Mount Crawford continues to burn but has been contained.Another fire in the Gawler Ranges at Mt Granite, west of Scrubby Peak, was burning in a an inaccessible part of the park, with bush walkers and campers warned to avoid the area.

urn:contentItem:5P2G-SFK1-JD34-V0HW-00000-00Celebrating return of traditional knowledge2017-07-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Celebrating return of traditional knowledgeNatalie Croxon

Aboriginal elders have have returned to one of the sites where traditional Aboriginal burning practices were first reintroduced to the Victorian landscape.

The first burns, conducted at Whipstick and Maryborough in May, marked a significant milestone in the recognition of Aboriginal heritage in Victoria, with traditional practices incorporated into land management.

On Wednesday, elders and other members of the Dja Dja Wurrung community held a ceremony at the site of the Whipstick burn.

The site has been named Djandak Wi, which means 'fire country' in the Dja Dja Wurrung language.

The return of traditional practices has been a partnership between the Dja Dja Wurrung Clans Aboriginal Corporation and Forest Fire Management Victoria.

Uncle Gary Nelson said it was important for the Aboriginal community to make connections with the broader community, while Uncle Tom Baksh said it was pleasing to see younger Aboriginal people take the lead with such initiatives.

urn:contentItem:5NNK-NH01-F0JP-W1V1-00000-00Firewood collector charged2017-05-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 15Firewood collector chargedBy SHANNON TWOMEY

A 64-YEAR-OLD Koondrook man has been fined after breaching firewood collection regulations in Gunbower State Forest.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's Nick Whatley said the man was found cutting and removing about two cubic metres of wood outside a designated firewood collection area.

"The man received an infringement notice and the wood was seized and impounded," Mr Whatley said.

"People who cut down trees, collect firewood outside designated firewood collection areas or a firewood collection season, take more than the maximum allowable amounts or sell firewood they have collected can face on-the-spot fines of $622, or a maximum penalty for more serious offences of $7773 or one year imprisonment or both."For a full list of firewood regulations and designated firewood collection areas, go to delwp.vic.gov.au

urn:contentItem:5N89-6S21-F0JP-W4GV-00000-00More smoke on horizon2017-04-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 12More smoke on horizon

SMOKE over the Otways will be a familiar sight over the coming days with planned burns by Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMV) continuing.

The fire will cover 380ha at Big Hill and was ignited on Tuesday. More than 60 firefighters are involved in the multi-day operation.

FFMV Otway district manager David Rourke said he expected the operation to be completed sometime over the weekend. Crews will continue to patrol the burn area for a number of days until it is declared safe.

"Our aircraft will be a regular sight near the Great Ocean Road until at least Saturday afternoon, as aerial ignition and waterbombing activities continue," Mr Rourke said.This is the fourth autumn planned burn, and follows similar activities near Kennett River, Cressy and Breamlea.

urn:contentItem:5MW7-54F1-JD34-V03W-00000-00Popular nature trail ruined by DELWP2017-02-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Popular nature trail ruined by DELWPWilliam Vallely

HUNDREDS of trees lay prone beside a popular nature trail in Whroo state forest, near Rushworth.

The Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning fell the trees to better police the public trail, which was regularly used by motor cross riders.

The trail was created after the installation of a Telstra cable years ago, and had become a popular nature trail for locals and tourists.

But for Forest Fire Management Victoria District Manager at the department, Paul Bates, it had become unmanageable.

Signs designed to stop illegal motor cross riders didn't work, and the track was rarely maintained by the department, according to Mr Bates.

"The actions we have taken are driven by pubic safety," he said.

urn:contentItem:5NV3-NC11-JD34-V23J-00000-00Autumn firewood collection season nears end2017-06-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:19ZLexisNexisAutumn firewood collection season nears end

Firewood collectors in central Victoria will have to stock up by the end of the month or wait till September, with the autumn season due to close across the state on June 30.

Forest Fire Management Victoria spokesman Peter Kambouris also reminded residents to make sure they only collected wood from open, designated collection areas.

"FFMV cannot guarantee firewood will be available at all sites and where available, it will be of varying sizes and quality," he said.

"It is illegal to sell firewood collected on public land without an appropriate permit or licence or to take more than the allowed amount."

People who collect firewood illegally, take more than the maximum allowable amounts or sell firewood they have collected can face fines or imprisonment.

The spring firewood collection season will open on September 1.

To find a designated firewood collection area visit www.ffm.vic.gov.au/firewood/firewood-collection-in-your-region

urn:contentItem:5R2V-TWH1-F0J6-J1F4-00000-00Lightning strikes keep forest firefighters busy as fire season begins2017-12-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Lightning strikes keep forest firefighters busy as fire season begins

Forest Fire Management Victoria crews have battled 91 fires across the state since last Wednesday in a busy start to the fire season.

Of the 91 fires on public land, two were in the Murray Goldfields region.

FFMV senior fire management officer Jeff Wilkie said a lightning strike started a fire in Joseph Young Drive, Mount Alexander, last Friday.

"The Helitac out of Bendigo extinguished that fire pretty quickly. The storm went across at 5.45pm and the strike happened at 6.20pm," Mr Wilkie said.

Another fire was deliberately lit in Long Gully Creek, North Bendigo, last Saturday.

"That fire is under investigation. We were contacted by the fire tower at 2.35pm and assisted the CFA in controlling it," Mr Wilkie said.

In preparation for the fire season, FFMV crews have also been undertaking planned burns across the state with nine planned burns across 766 hectares in the Murray Goldfields region.

"It has been a busy start to the fire season, with lightning starting a significant number of fires," FFMV chief fire officer Stephanie Rotarangi said.
